# Chapter 7: Basic Types
This chapter discussed the basic types in C including int, float and char as well as their long and short versions
## Exercises

### 1. Decimal Values 
![alt text](<./Screenshots/ex1.png>)

Wrote a short program for this that prints the values as below:

#### (a) 63
#### (b) 119
#### (c) 2748

### 2. Legal Constants
![alt text](<./Screenshots/ex2.png>)
#### (a) Not legal because it begins with a 0 denoting an octal number but also has an E used in floats

#### (b) legal floating constant

#### (c) legal octal integer constant

#### (d) Not legal as underscores are not allowed in integers

#### (e) legal floating point constant
 
### 3. Legal Types
![alt text](<./Screenshots/ex3.png>)

#### (a) Legal - same as unsigned short int

#### (b) Not legal - short cannot be used with float

#### (c) Legal - larger sized double

#### (d) Legal - same as unsigned long int

### 4. Legal Char Statements
![alt text](<./Screenshots/ex4.png>)

(d) is illegal because printf takes a string as an argument. The correct way to pass the char through printf would be `printf("%c", c)`

### 5. Legal Way to Write 65
All are legal ways to write 65 according to my interpreter.

### 6. Smallest data types

#### (a) Days in a month is max 31 so char would be the smallest possible type with a max of 255

#### (b) days in a year is 365 which is greater than 255 for char but small enough to fit in a short

#### (c) minutes in a day = 60 * 24 = 1440. Again too large for char but would fit into a short

#### (d) seconds in a day = 60 * 60 * 24 = 86400. Too large for char but depending on the system could fit into a short or int

### 7. Octal escapes

#### (a) \b = \010

#### (b) \n = \012

#### (c) \r = \015

#### (d) \t = \011

### 8. Hexadecimal escapes

#### (a) \b = \0x8

#### (b) \n = \0xA

#### (c) \r = \0xF

#### (d) \t = \0x9

### 9. expression type

For the expression, i / j + 'a', the type will be an int because the char 'a' will be promoted to an int.

### 10. 
![alt text](<./Screenshots/ex10.png>)

The other variables will all be implicitly converted to long 

### 11. 
![alt text](<./Screenshots/ex11.png>)

The other variables will all be converted double

### 12. 
![alt text](<./Screenshots/ex12.png>)

In i + f the i is converted to a float and added to f. d = i + f the i + f is then converted to a double to be assigned to d.

### 13.
![alt text](<./Screenshots/ex13.png>)

#### (a) value: -3, type: signed int

#### (b) value: 7, type: long int

#### (c) value: 6.5f, type: float

#### (d) value: 3.75, type: double

#### (e) value: -1.0, type: double

#### (f) value: 6, type: int

### 14. 
![alt text](<./Screenshots/ex14.png>)

Tested this out with some code in ex14.c the fractional part seemed to be always correct compared to the float. The float did behave strangely though not rounding up to the nearest tenth

### 15. typedefs

On my machine, chars are 8bit, short ints are 16bit and ints are 32bit so in ex15.c I created typedefs for Int8, Int16 and Int32 using those three types.

## Projects

### 1. square2.c testing

The maximum int value the user can enter before the code starts to fail is 46340. This is because 46341 squared is greater than 2^31- which is largest number a 32 bit signed integer can be.

Something interesting happens when setting i to be short int. If i is greater than or equal to 2^15 - 1 then it will loop forever because i will never be greater than n.

### 2. square2.c modified

Modified the above to stop and prompt the user every 24 squares with a getchar and only continues when the user presses enter

### 3. sum2.c modified

modified the sum2.c program to sum doubles instead of ints

### 4. phoneNum.c

This program will convert an alphabetical phone number into numbers according to the keypad of a phone. This was done using a switch which assigns 'A' through 'Z' to their corresponding values

### 5. scrabbleScore.c

Outputs a scrabble score for any word given by the user:

    Enter a word: quiz
    Scrabble value: 22

### 6. sizeOfType.c

Prints the sizes of several different types:

    Size of int: 4
    Size of short: 2
    Size of long: 8
    Size of float: 4
    Size of double: 8
    Size of long double: 16

Potentially useful for checking specs of your machine.

### 7. frac.c

This is a modified version of addFrac.c from chapter 3. It now lets you add, subtract, multiply and divide 2 fractions:

    Enter two fractions (separated by +,-,*,/): 1/2+1/2
    The sum is 4/4

    Enter two fractions (separated by +,-,*,/): 1/3 * 1/3
    The sum is 1/9

    Enter two fractions (separated by +,-,*,/): 7/4 / 3/8
    The sum is 56/12

### 8. flights.c 

Modified version of flights.c from chapter 5. This one takes a 12 hour clock input instead:

    Enter a 12-hour time: 12:45am
    Closest departure time is 08:00 a.m., arriving at 10:16 a.m.

### 9. timeConverter.c

Another modified program from chapter 5. Converts from 12 hour time to 24 hour time:

    Enter a 12-hour time: 08:30PM
    Equivalent 24-hour time: 20:30

### 10. vowelCount.c

counts number of vowels in a sentence: 

    Enter a sentence: good doggy
    Your sentence contains 3 vowels.

### 11. name.c

Asks the user to enter a first and last name and then outputs the name in the format Lastname, F.

    Enter a first and last name: Isaac Pemberton
    Pemberton, I.

### 12. evaluate.c

A program that evaluates any expression that uses +,-,* or /. 

    Enter an expression: 80.75*45.3/23.2+98.5
    Value of expression: 256.171326

### 13. wordLength.c

Displays the average word length for a given sentence:

    Enter a sentence: Hello how are you my friend!
    Average word length: 3.8

### 14. newtonRoot.c

Uses Newton's method to find the square root of a number:

    Enter a positive number: 12
    Square root: 3.464102

### 15. factorial.c

This outputs the factorial of a number chosen by the user:

    Enter a positive integer: 6
    Factorial of 6: 720

#### (a) using a short

Using a short int for factorial, n = 7 is the highest value of n before the factorial starts to print incorrectly: 

    Enter a positive integer: 7
    Factorial of 7: 5040

    Enter a positive integer: 8
    Factorial of 8: -25216 

As you can see for n = 8, factorial overflows and shows as a negative number

#### (b) using an int

after n = 13, it starts to overflow and shows an incorrect value:

    Enter a positive integer: 12
    Factorial of 12: 479001600

    Enter a positive integer: 13
    Factorial of 13: 1932053504 (should be 6227020800)

#### (c) using a long

Starts to fail after n = 20:

    Enter a positive integer: 20
    Factorial of 20: 2432902008176640000 (Correct)

    Enter a positive integer: 21
    Factorial of 21: -4249290049419214848 (Not so correct)

#### (d) using a long long

my compiler doesn't support long long

#### (e) using a float

Approximates very well up until 35 where it starts to just say inf:

    Enter a positive integer: 34
    Factorial of 34: 295232883843762098116370704180633927680.000000

    Enter a positive integer: 35
    Factorial of 35: inf

#### (f) using a double

Approximates until 170:

    Enter a positive integer: 170
    Factorial of 170: .000000

    Enter a positive integer: 171
    Factorial of 171: inf

#### (g) using a long double

Approximates until n = 1754: 

Enter a positive integer: 1754
    Factorial of 1754: .0000005843401792591456329221146795771636951116670362654762390032451815950158958724325081732532483994655489671710250326816319815290383686425762390409692314045366609911370654841242124288.000000

    Enter a positive integer: 1755
    Factorial of 1755: inf
